query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 «O sodalizio eletto a la gran cena 2 del benedetto Agnello, il qual vi ciba 3 sì, che la vostra voglia è sempre piena,
4 se per grazia di Dio questi preliba 5 di quel che cade de la vostra mensa, 6 prima che morte tempo li prescriba,
7 ponete mente a l’affezione immensa 8 e roratelo alquanto: voi bevete 9 sempre del fonte onde vien quel ch’ei pensa».
query.result:
**English:**
1 “O company chosen for the great supper 2 of the blessed Lamb, who feeds you 3 so that your desire is always fulfilled,
4 if by the grace of God this man tastes 5 of that which falls from your table, 6 before death prescribes a time for him,
7 consider his immense affection 8 and sprinkle him with a little: you always drink 9 from the source from which comes that which he thinks.”
**Cornish:**
1 “O sodaliti ethol dhe'n vras keni 2 a'n Oen bennakys, ow a'th voos, 3 lemmyn an wolesow yw symyns leun,
4 mar gans gras a Dhew an preliba ma 5 a henna ow a kodh a'th voos, 6 kyns na wra'n marow a-dhemedh dhodho,
7 settyth myns dhe'n affection immensa 8 ha rorythy ytho byghan: why a yv 9 symyns a'n fenten ow a dheghowgh henna ow a vyn.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Così Beatrice; e quelle anime liete 11 si fero spere sopra fissi poli, 12 fiammando, a volte, a guisa di comete.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Thus Beatrice; and those joyful souls 11 made themselves into spheres above fixed poles, 12 flaming, in turn, like comets.
**Cornish:**
10 Vel henna Beatrice; ha henna enefow lowen 11 a wrug spereow war-ves poliow fast, 12 ow flammow, yn tro, kepar cometow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Però salta la penna e non lo scrivo: 26 ché l’imagine nostra a cotai pieghe, 27 non che ’l parlare, è troppo color vivo.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Therefore my pen leaps and does not write it: 26 because our imagination to such heights, 27 not to mention speech, is too weak a color.
**Cornish:**
25 Rag henna an benna a wra’n ow lam ha nyns a skrifsa, 26 rag an ymajination vy dhe henna ughelow, 27 nyns lemmyn an lavar, yw liw mor bleg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 «O santa suora mia che sì ne prieghe 29 divota, per lo tuo ardente affetto 30 da quella bella spera mi disleghe».
query.result:
**English:**
28 “O my holy sister who prays for us so 29 devoutly, because of your ardent affection 30 release me from that beautiful sphere.”
**Cornish:**
28 “O vy santes sor vy ow a wra’n ow pedas dhe’n moy 29 ow devota, rag an wolesow lowen, 30 a henna spera brassa owth dhilegha.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Poscia fermato, il foco benedetto 32 a la mia donna dirizzò lo spiro, 33 che favellò così com’ i’ ho detto.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Then, having stopped, the blessed fire 32 directed its breath towards my lady, 33 who spoke just as I have said.
**Cornish:**
31 Wosahagsew, an tan benygys 32 dhe'm benen a-dro dhe'm mestra, 33 hag eth omladra avel henna a leveris.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Ed ella: «O luce etterna del gran viro 35 a cui Nostro Segnor lasciò le chiavi, 36 ch’ei portò giù, di questo gaudio miro,
37 tenta costui di punti lievi e gravi, 38 come ti piace, intorno de la fede, 39 per la qual tu su per lo mare andavi.
query.result:
**English:**
34 And she: "O eternal light of the great man 35 to whom Our Lord left the keys, 36 which he carried down, of this wondrous joy,
37 test this man with easy and difficult questions, 38 as you please, concerning the faith, 39 for which you once walked upon the sea.
**Cornish:**
34 Hag hithy: "O golow sempeter an gwreydh bras 35 dhe dh'y skoodhas an Arluth ni an allwedhow, 36 a dhiskynnas ev dhe'n lowena magh,
37 prof an den-ma na bennansow es ha dowr, 38 kepar ha kar, a-dro dhe'n feyth, 39 rag an keth a-dro dhe'n mor."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Sì come il baccialier s’arma e non parla 47 fin che ’l maestro la question propone, 48 per approvarla, non per terminarla,
49 così m’armava io d’ogne ragione 50 mentre ch’ella dicea, per esser presto 51 a tal querente e a tal professione.
query.result:
**English:**
46 Just as the bachelor arms himself and does not speak 47 until the master proposes the question, 48 in order to approve it, not to conclude it,
49 so I armed myself with every argument 50 while she was speaking, in order to be ready 51 for such a questioner and such a profession.
**Cornish:**
46 Kepar ha'n yonklergh a wra s'arvia ha na lever 47 bys mayster an govyn a wra goniso, 48 rag y apruvya, na rag y termynya,
49 hemma wra'm s'arvia gans pub reson 50 tramor a leveris, rag bos prest 51 dhe'n govyn ha'n professo kepar hyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 «La Grazia che mi dà ch’io mi confessi», 59 comincia’ io, «da l’alto primipilo, 60 faccia li miei concetti bene espressi».
query.result:
**English:**
58 "The Grace that grants me to confess myself", 59 I began, "from the high commander, 60 may make my thoughts well expressed".
**Cornish:**
58 "An Gras a ro dhiso dhe'm a wra gonfessa", 59 a leveris 'vy, "a'n Uhella Chif Kaptan, 60 a wra gwruthyl va konsepsow dhe vos dallethys".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 E seguitai: «Come ’l verace stilo 62 ne scrisse, padre, del tuo caro frate 63 che mise teco Roma nel buon filo,
64 fede è sustanza di cose sperate 65 e argomento de le non parventi; 66 e questa pare a me sua quiditate».
query.result:
**English:**
61 And I continued: "As the true pen 62 wrote of it, father, of your dear brother 63 who, with you, set Rome on the right path,
64 faith is the substance of things hoped for, 65 and the evidence of things not seen; 66 and this seems to me to be its quiddity".
**Cornish:**
61 Ha'm leveris: "Kepar ha'n stil wir a skrifas, 62 tas, O tas, a-dro dhe'th froder ker, 63 a ros Roma gansos war an fordh da,
64 feyth yw substans a-dro traow sperys, 65 ha argumens a-dro traow na wra gweles; 66 ha henna a wra dhe'm y 'quiddity'".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Allora udi’: «Dirittamente senti, 68 se bene intendi perché la ripuose 69 tra le sustanze, e poi tra li argomenti».
query.result:
**English:**
67 Then I heard: "You understand correctly, 68 if you understand well why he placed it 69 among the substances, and then among the evidences".
**Cornish:**
67 Wosa henna'm klev: "Yn dalleth te a wra klev, 68 mar te a wra dalleth pyth ev a ros 69 ynter an substansow, ha wosa henna ynter an argumensow".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 E io appresso: «Le profonde cose 71 che mi largiscon qui la lor parvenza, 72 a li occhi di là giù son sì ascose,
73 che l’esser loro v’è in sola credenza, 74 sopra la qual si fonda l’alta spene; 75 e però di sustanza prende intenza.
query.result:
**English:**
70 And I continued: "The profound things 71 that here grant me their appearance, 72 to the eyes down there are so hidden,
73 that their existence there is only in belief, 74 upon which high hope is founded; 75 and therefore it takes on the meaning of substance.
**Cornish:**
70 Ha'm leveris: "An traow dowr a ro dhe'm yma aga parvenza, 71 dhe'n lagha a-ves yw keudhis kovys,
72 bys na wra gwrys ynno marnas kredens, 74 war an keth yw fondys an spens uhella; 75 ha dre henna ev a wra kemer an styr a substans".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 E da questa credenza ci convene 77 silogizzar, sanz’ avere altra vista: 78 però intenza d’argomento tene».
query.result:
**English:**
76 And from this belief we must 77 syllogize, without having any other vision: 78 therefore it takes on the meaning of evidence.
**Cornish:**
76 Ha a'n kredens-ma ny yw rekis 77 dhe syllogisa, heb bos gwrys aral gweles: 78 dre henna ev a wra kemer an styr a argumens.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Allora udi’: «Se quantunque s’acquista 80 giù per dottrina, fosse così ’nteso, 81 non lì avria loco ingegno di sofista».
query.result:
**English:**
79 Then I heard: "If whatever is acquired 80 through learning were understood in this way, 81 there would be no place for the ingenuity of a sophist".
**Cornish:**
79 Anwedhenna'm: "Mar plywma'gan pyth whyth 80 a-woles gans dyskans, o ve komprehendys, 81 nyns eussey le unn le sofist".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
86 Ond’ io: «Sì ho, sì lucida e sì tonda, 87 che nel suo conio nulla mi s’inforsa».
88 Appresso uscì de la luce profonda 89 che lì splendeva: «Questa cara gioia 90 sopra la quale ogne virtù si fonda,
91 onde ti venne?». E io: «La larga ploia 92 de lo Spirito Santo, ch’è diffusa 93 in su le vecchie e ’n su le nuove cuoia,
94 è silogismo che la m’ha conchiusa 95 acutamente sì, che ’nverso d’ella 96 ogne dimostrazion mi pare ottusa».
query.result:
**English:**
86 And I: "Yes, I have it, so bright and round, 87 that nothing in its imprint is unclear to me".
88 Then from the deep light 89 that shone there, he came forth: "This dear joy 90 on which every virtue is founded,
91 where did it come to you from?". And I: "The broad rain 92 of the Holy Spirit, which is spread 93 over the old and the new scriptures,
94 is the syllogism that has concluded it for me 95 so acutely that, compared to it, 96 every other demonstration seems obtuse to me".
**Cornish:**
86 Ha henna: "Ia, kler ha krenn, heb dowt, 87 Yn y'gan stamp nyns eus trass vyth dhym".
88 Wosa henna a-dhyworth an golon downder 89 O'th omglewya: "An kara lowen ma 90 Yn aga hanter oll vertusow a-fonda,
91 A-dhyworth le mayth?". Ha henna: "An brassa glaw 92 A'gan Spyrys Sans, ow t'eth ledyes 93 War an hen ha'n nowydh koweth,
94 Syllogism yw ow t'eth provyas 95 Yn kler dhe'm, pub trass vyth dhym a-ves 96 A-gemmys dhe'm yn dowt".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Io udi’ poi: «L’antica e la novella 98 proposizion che così ti conchiude, 99 perché l’hai tu per divina favella?».
query.result:
**English:**
97 Then I heard: "The old and the new 98 proposition that concludes you thus, 99 why do you hold it to be divine speech?".
**Cornish:**
97 Ha henna a glewas: "An hen ha'n nowydh 98 Proposizion ow t'eth provyas vel, 99 Ragadow t'eth hemma avel lavar Duw?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 E io: «La prova che ’l ver mi dischiude, 101 son l’opere seguite, a che natura 102 non scalda ferro mai né batte incude».
query.result:
**English:**
100 And I: "The proof that discloses the truth to me 101 is the works that follow, for which nature 102 never heats iron or strikes an anvil".
**Cornish:**
100 Ha henna: "An prof a-dhiskwedh an gwir vyth, 101 An oberow ow sew, rag natur 102 Nyns a-wella howarn po na-wella kov".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Risposto fummi: «Dì, chi t’assicura 104 che quell’ opere fosser? Quel medesmo 105 che vuol provarsi, non altri, il ti giura».
query.result:
**English:**
103 He answered me: "Tell me, who assures you 104 that those works were [the works of God]? The very same 105 who wants to be proved, and no other, swears it to you".
**Cornish:**
103 Ev a-wosa dhym: "Dywedh, pyw t'eth syur 104 Ev an oberow henna? An unnik 105 A-vynn provyas y honan, heb aral, t'eth lowr".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 «Se ’l mondo si rivolse al cristianesmo», 107 diss’ io, «sanza miracoli, quest’ uno 108 è tal, che li altri non sono il centesmo:
109 ché tu intrasti povero e digiuno 110 in campo, a seminar la buona pianta 111 che fu già vite e ora è fatta pruno».
query.result:
**English:**
106 "If the world turned to Christianity", 107 I said, "without miracles, this one 108 is such that the others are not even a hundredth of it:
109 for you entered the field poor and fasting, 110 to sow the good plant 111 that was once a vine and is now become a thorn".
**Cornish:**
106 "Mar an bys a droas dhe'n Kristoniet", 107 Me a leveris, "heb meur ras, henna 108 Avel, an erel nyns eus par dhe'n kans:
109 Rag thy a-dhyworth yn bover ha digiwn 110 Yn mayth, rag sew an plann da 111 O'th omglewya gwinvydh, mes prun yw ena".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Finito questo, l’alta corte santa 113 risonò per le spere un ‘Dio laudamo’ 114 ne la melode che là sù si canta.
query.result:
**English:**
112 When this was finished, the high and holy court 113 resounded through the spheres with a 'We praise God' 114 in the melody that is sung up there.
**Cornish:**
112 Wosa henna, an uhella lys sans 113 A-glewas a-dro dhe'n sphiriow oll 114 Yn an melodi a-gan kaner ena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 E quel baron che sì di ramo in ramo, 116 essaminando, già tratto m’avea, 117 che a l’ultime fronde appressavamo,
118 ricominciò: «La Grazia, che donnea 119 con la tua mente, la bocca t’aperse 120 infino a qui come aprir si dovea,
121 sì ch’io approvo ciò che fuori emerse; 122 ma or convien espremer quel che credi, 123 e onde a la credenza tua s’offerse».
query.result:
**English:**
115 And that baron who had drawn me thus, 116 examining me from branch to branch, 117 so that we were approaching the topmost leaves,
118 began again: "The Grace that endows 119 your mind has opened your mouth 120 up to this point as far as it should be opened,
121 so that I approve what has come forth; 122 but now you must express what you believe, 123 and from where your belief came to you".
**Cornish:**
115 Ha'n baron henna a'm ladhas a-dhyworth 116 Gans an avalow, ow provyas vyth, 117 Yn-dann dhe'n diwettha foliow omglew,
118 A-dallethas: "An Gras a-dhiskwedh 119 Yn aga dh'aga medhel, t'eth geus agan 120 Bythma henna a-dhallethas,
121 Vel, henna'm a-brov an pyth a-dhyworth; 122 Mes ena rydh dyskwedhes pyth a-grys, 123 Ha a-dhyworth le mayth t'eth offrys".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 «O santo padre, e spirito che vedi 125 ciò che credesti sì, che tu vincesti 126 ver’ lo sepulcro più giovani piedi»,
127 comincia’ io, «tu vuo’ ch’io manifesti 128 la forma qui del pronto creder mio, 129 e anche la cagion di lui chiedesti.
query.result:
**English:**
124 "O holy father, and spirit who see 125 what you believed so that you overcame 126 younger feet to the sepulchre",
127 I began, "you want me to declare 128 the form of my ready belief here, 129 and you have also asked the reason for it.
**Cornish:**
124 "O sans sans, ha sperys a-wel 125 Pyth a-grysis vel, bys vyth gorfen 126 Yn-dann dhe'n bez dhe'n trayn yonk esa",
127 Me a-dallethas, "Thy a-vynn dyskwedhes 128 An furv a'm grys prest ena, 129 Ha'n resen dhe'n ef a-wynn gofyn".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 De la profonda condizion divina 143 ch’io tocco mo, la mente mi sigilla 144 più volte l’evangelica dottrina.
query.result:
**English:**
142 From the profound divine condition 143 that I touch now, my mind is sealed 144 many times by the evangelical doctrine.
**Cornish:**
142 A-dhyworth an dowr dhiwin dowr 143 ow toshyn vy dhe’n termyn ma, an meyn a seli 144 lies ha lies gans an doktrin Awenek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
145 Quest’ è ’l principio, quest’ è la favilla 146 che si dilata in fiamma poi vivace, 147 e come stella in cielo in me scintilla».
query.result:
**English:**
145 This is the beginning, this is the spark 146 that then expands into a lively flame, 147 and like a star in the sky it sparkles in me».
**Cornish:**
145 Henn yw an dalleth, henn yw an spark 146 a dheles yn flam ow tressa byw, 147 ha kepar steren yn an nev a wravia yn-y’m».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
148 Come ’l segnor ch’ascolta quel che i piace, 149 da indi abbraccia il servo, gratulando 150 per la novella, tosto ch’el si tace;
151 così, benedicendomi cantando, 152 tre volte cinse me, sì com’ io tacqui, 153 l’appostolico lume al cui comando
154 io avea detto: sì nel dir li piacqui!
query.result:
**English:**
148 Like the lord who listens to what pleases him, 149 then embraces the servant, congratulating him 150 for the news, as soon as he is silent;
151 so, blessing me while singing, 152 he encircled me three times, as soon as I was silent, 153 the apostolic light at whose command
154 I had spoken: so much did he like me in my speaking!
**Cornish:**
148 Kepar an argluydh a glewses an peth a wravia dhe, 149 wosa henna a golla an servas, owth usi, 150 rag an nowodhow, pub sodho ef a wravia;
151 kepar henna, ow bendithya ow kanna, 152 ef a’m kolas tri gweyth, pub sodho ef a wravia, 153 an golon Apostolik dhe’n komandans
154 owth leveris: moon dhe’n leverel a wravia dhe!
